caption_original: The Canadian Coast Guard, together with the Canadian Armed Forces – Joint Task Force Pacific, Emergency Management BC, British Columbia Emergency Health Services, Public Safety Canada and BC Ferries, among other partners, will be leading a major maritime disaster exercise called “Exercise Salish Sea” east of Salt Spring Island, British Columbia on October 25 & 26. Tomorrow we will share highlights from Day 1, which will focus on the rescue of over 100 “survivors” from a BC Ferries’ vessel M/V Coastal Renaissance. A total of 15 vessels and four aircraft are being employed. BC Ferries Royal Canadian Marine Search & Rescue • Station 1 - West Vancouver Maritime Forces Pacific / Forces maritimes du Pacifique

Tomorrow we will share highlights from Day , which will focus on the rescue of over “survivors” from a BC Ferries’ vessel M/V Coastal Renaissance. A total of vessels and four aircraft are being employed. BC Ferries Royal Canadian Marine Search & Rescue • Station - West Vancouver Maritime Forces Pacific / Forces maritimes du Pacifique

caption_original:
Today we were on the water east of Salt Spring Island, British Columbia, with partners, participating in day one of a two-day major maritime incident training exercise called “Exercise Salish Sea”. This training exercise is the largest major exercise in Canadian Coast Guard history. Today’s scenario involved the evacuation of 100 ‘survivors’ from a participating BC Ferries’ vessel. Some were evacuated into vessels in the water, and some hoists of evacuees were simulated by our colleagues in the Canadian Armed Forces and US Coast Guard. 

Environmental Response will be the focus of tomorrow’s activities. Partners participating in Exercise Salish Sea include: Canadian Armed Forces, Canadian Coast Guard, Transport and Infrastructure in Canada, BC Ferries, BC Emergency Health Services, Emergency Management BC, BC Ministry of Environment, Royal Canadian Marine Search and Rescue, the U.S. Coast Guard and Western Canada Marine Response Organization, among a great many others. Special thanks today to the community on Salt Spring Island, where our ‘casualties’ were brought ashore.

Special thanks today to the community on Salt Spring Island, where our ‘casualties’ were brought ashore.

caption_original: On this Persons Day, we would like to feature a very powerful woman in the Canadian Coast Guard, Assistant Commissioner Julie Gascon. Assistant Commissioner Gascon began her journey with us as a student at the Canadian Coast Guard College and is now the head of our Central & Arctic Region, which includes over 1,200 employees. She also regularly speaks at workshops designed to help empower women. Claim Your Place! Women in Canada

caption_original: Rare visit by two Snowy Owl that stopped to hitch a ride aboard CCGS Sir Wilfrid Laurier, in the Chukchi Sea in the Arctic . One landed near the front and one landed near the back of the ship as it was making its way further North to a mooring recovery site at 75N 168W. Once the ship turned south, the pair flew off!

One landed near the front and one landed near the back of the ship as it was making its way further North to a mooring recovery site at N W. Once the ship turned south, the pair flew off!

caption_original:
Congratulations to our newest Marine Communications and Traffic Services (MCTS) graduates! 
 
MCTS Officers are incredibly vital to the Coast Guard, and to all Canadians. Their work saves lives and helps protect our environment. 
 
We are CCG Proud and wish you all the best!

caption_original:
Today we were again on the water east of Salt Spring Island, British Columbia, with partners, participating in day two of a two-day major maritime exercise called “Exercise Salish Sea”. Our Canadian Coast Guard Ship Bartlett stood in for the ferry which was on scene yesterday. Partners practiced working together on marine environmental response techniques.

This two day exercise involved approximately 500 people from more than 20 government and non-governmental organizations – including local Indigenous peoples from several Coastal First Nations. A total of 15 vessels and four aircraft were employed. 

Big thanks to everyone who worked with us on both days! Canadian Armed Forces Transport and Infrastructure in Canada BCFerries BC Emergency Health Services, Emergency Management BC, BC Ministry of Environment, Royal Canadian Marine Search and Rescue U.S. Coast Guard Western Canada Marine Response Organization.

This two day exercise involved approximately people from more than government and non-governmental organizations – including local Indigenous peoples from several Coastal First Nations. A total of vessels and four aircraft were employed. Big thanks to everyone who worked with us on both days! Canadian Armed Forces Transport and Infrastructure in Canada BCFerries BC Emergency Health Services, Emergency Management BC, BC Ministry of Environment, Royal Canadian Marine Search and Rescue U.S. Coast Guard Western Canada Marine Response Organization.

caption_original:
Icebreakers which have spent the summer in the Arctic are beginning to return to their home ports. Tomorrow, watch the arrival of the first one, the CCGS Pierre Radisson, back in Quebec City after a trip to Iceland. As part of this expedition, the Canadian Coast Guard participated in the Arctic Coast Guard Forum. 

The live exercise allowed the Canadian Coast Guard to demonstrate its world-leading abilities in search and rescue operations in partnership with the other seven countries participating. 

Learn more about the Forum: ow.ly/VJDW30fDV7b

The live exercise allowed the Canadian Coast Guard to demonstrate its world-leading abilities in search and rescue operations in partnership with the other seven countries participating. caption_original: The CCGS Sir Wilfrid Laurier crew recently recovered science moorings in rough seas in the western Arctic. Besides Coast Guard work (icebreaking, escorts, aids to navigation, community visits etc.), the ship supports several collaborative partnerships during its annual Arctic operations. Time in the North is maximized with this important scientific research just prior to the ship starting its return trip south, to its homeport in Victoria, BC.

On her annual voyage south from the Arctic, CCGS Sir Wilfrid Laurier and her crew encountered the ubiquitous weather, all-too common in the Bering Sea, especially in the month of October.

Not for the faint of heart, the seasoned sailors with the Coast Guard are up for the challenge! #CCGProud.

caption_original: This video from the Coast Guard features an inclusive rescue technique that makes it easier for smaller-statured people to rescue people of all sizes. This method is helping to eliminate gender and other diversity barriers for Coast Guard members. Claim your place! Women in Canada

caption_original:
Ahoy! An opportunistic meeting of two Coast Guard icebreakers in the Beaufort Sea in early October, facilitated the transfer of a hydrographer and some science samples from CCGS Sir Wilfrid Laurier to CCGS Louis S. St-Laurent. 

CCGS Sir Wilfrid Laurier had been conducting a mooring program, just prior to starting its journey south to its homeport in our Pacific Region.  CCGS Louis S. St-Laurent was finishing up a month-long science program in the Beaufort Sea before heading to Kugluktuk for a crew change and then sailing on to Milne Inlet for icebreaking operations in the Eastern Arctic before eventually heading to its homeport in our Atlantic Region. 

All missions accomplished; ships, personnel and science samples on their way to their final destinations! Bravo Zulu on a great #Arctic season. #CCG Proud.

St-Laurent was finishing up a month-long science program in the Beaufort Sea before heading to Kugluktuk for a crew change and then sailing on to Milne Inlet for icebreaking operations in the Eastern Arctic before eventually heading to its homeport in our Atlantic Region. All missions accomplished; ships, personnel and science samples on their way to their final destinations! Bravo Zulu on a great season. Proud.

caption_original: Ann Harvey (1811-1860). Born in Isle aux Morts, Newfoundland, the daughter of a fisherman and the eldest of eight children she often spent time helping her father. While fishing in July 1828, they noticed debris floating in the water, and realized that there was a shipwreck nearby. Ann Harvey, her father, twelve year old brother, and the family dog went out in their boat to locate the wreck, and found a large group of survivors on a tiny island. The family managed to save more than 160 people, and the rescue became famous across province. Ann Harvey became known as the Grace Darling of Newfoundland (from an English woman who participated in a similar rescue). http://ow.ly/Kbt630dblWW
caption_cleaned: Ann Harvey (1811-1860). Born in Isle aux Morts, Newfoundland, the daughter of a fisherman and the eldest of eight children she often spent time helping her father. While fishing in July , they noticed debris floating in the water, and realized that there was a shipwreck nearby. Ann Harvey, her father, twelve year old brother, and the family dog went out in their boat to locate the wreck, and found a large group of survivors on a tiny island. The family managed to save more than people, and the rescue became famous across province. Ann Harvey became known as the Grace Darling of Newfoundland (from an English woman who participated in a similar rescue).

caption_original:
CCGS Des Groseilliers returns to Quebec City tomorrow after its annual Arctic mission. During its expedition, supplies were provided to the Eureka weather station on Ellesmere Island. The vessel also escorted the cruise ship Le Boréal through the ice.
To find out more about the icebreaker: ow.ly/fsFV30fHIZ0

caption_original:
We spoke with 300 First Nations students during an annual Aboriginal Youth Career Awareness. 

This year, the Chippewas of Kettle and Stony Point hosted the two-day event on the powwow grounds along the shores of Lake Huron at Kettle Point. 

We look forward to participating again next year!

caption_original: CCGS GC-03 returns to Quebec harbour after its day of operations on the St. Lawrence River. This small vessel, designed for hydrographic surveys and channel surveys, is used to monitor the depth of water in the St. Lawrence Seaway between Sault-au-Cochon and Montreal. Its work contributes to the safety of navigation. Like the Morillon and the CCGS F.C.G. Smith, CCGS GC-03 is in operation annually during the spring thaw to the end of November. http://ow.ly/XZze30flRoH

Its work contributes to the safety of navigation. Like the Morillon and the CCGS F.C.G. Smith, CCGS GC-03 is in operation annually during the spring thaw to the end of November.

caption_original:
The the CCGS Amundsen is returning home (Quebec City) on October 12, after having supported the 2nd edition of the Inuit Health Survey, in Nunavik, conducted by the Institut national de santé publique du Québec. It also enabled the BriGHT (Bridging Global Change, Inuit Health and Transforming Arctic Ocean) project of the Northern Sentinel Strategy, developed at Université Laval. It was its 13th scientific expendition in the Arctic.

To find out more: http://www.marinfo.gc.ca/en/Flotte/Amundsen.asp

It was its th scientific eendition in the Arctic. To find out more:

caption_original: On September 14, 2017, a delegation of 43 distinguished visitors from 19 countries toured CCGS Henry Larsen in Resolute Bay, Nunavut, while the icebreaker stopped there for a scheduled crew change. Most of the international visitors represented the NATO Parliamentary Assembly. Led by the Department of National Defence, this northern tour provided delegates with an opportunity to study and discuss Arctic issues related to climate change, international relations, security and cooperation.
caption_cleaned: On September , , a delegation of distinguished visitors from countries toured CCGS Henry Larsen in Resolute Bay, Nunavut, while the icebreaker stopped there for a scheduled crew change. Most of the international visitors represented the NATO Parliamentary Assembly. Led by the Department of National Defence, this northern tour provided delegates with an opportunity to study and discuss Arctic issues related to climate change, international relations, security and cooperation.

caption_original: FBF. On September 21, 2017, our Assistant Commissioner for the Central and Arctic Region, Julie Gascon, participated in the launch of the new, progressive Canada-EU Trade Agreement held at the Port of Montreal. Part of Coast Guard’s mandate is to ensure safe and efficient navigation of international merchant ships in Canada. As the new agreement is expected to result in increased ship traffic in the coming years, demand for Canadian Coast Guard services is also expected to increase.  Canada’s International Trade - Global Affairs Canada Find out about the Agreement here: http://ow.ly/vUMG30fR4A1

caption_original: Dr. Viola Davidson conducted the research for her M.Sc. and Ph.D. degrees on marine phytoplankton at the St. Andrews Biological Station from 1924-1932 as a volunteer investigator. At this time it was unusual for a woman to do graduate studies in marine science. Her later volunteer work (1947-48) was on salmon and eel movement at the Grand Lake rearing ponds at Wellington Station, Nova Scotia. Dr. Davidson was also a teacher at Central High School of Commerce in Toronto through the 1920s-1940s. She was a passionate and dedicated marine scientist. http://ow.ly/NVQt30fAgHI
caption_cleaned: Dr. Viola Davidson conducted the research for her M.Sc. and Ph.D. degrees on marine phytoplankton at the St. Andrews Biological Station from -1932 as a volunteer investigator. At this time it was unusual for a woman to do graduate studies in marine science. Her later volunteer work (1947-48) was on salmon and eel movement at the Grand Lake rearing ponds at Wellington Station, Nova Scotia. Dr. Davidson was also a teacher at Central High School of Commerce in Toronto through the s-1940s. She was a passionate and dedicated marine scientist.

caption_original:
We’re holding information sessions in multiple Arctic communities to ask college students how we can best spread the word about our recruitment efforts for the new Inshore Rescue Boat stations! Interested student can attend information sessions
Come find out more about the hiring process and requirements, and to provide your feedback. See photos for more information.  Please note: dates and times are subject to change.

ᑐᓴᐅᒪᑎᑦᑎᓂᐊᕋᑦᑕ ᓄᓇᓕᓂ ᐅᑭᐅᕐᑕᕐᑐᒥ ᐊᐱᕆᓂᐊᕐᕋᑎᒍ ᓯᓚᑐᓴᕐᕕᒃᒥᑐ ᐃᓕᓂᐊᕐᑐᑦ ᖃᓄᕐ ᖃᐅᔨᒪᑎᑎᒐᔭᕐᒪᖔᑦᑕ ᐃᖃᓇᐃᔭᕈᒪᔪᓂ ᕿᓂᕐᑎᓪᓗᑕ ᓄᑖᖑᔪᒧ ᓯᒃᔭᖓᓂ ᐸᕐᓴᐃᓂᕐᒧᑦ ᐅᒥᐊᑯᑦ ᓴᕿᑦᑐᖃᕐᓂᐊᕐᒪᑦ ᐃᓂᖃᕐᑎᑕᐅᓗᓂ! ᐃᓕᓂᐊᕐᑐᑦ ᐱᔪᒪᓂ ᐅᐸᖃᑕᐅᔪᓐᓇᕐᑐᑦ ᐅᑯᓇᓂ ᓄᓇᓕᒃᓂ. ᑕᑯᔭᕐᑐᕐᓂᐊᕐᐳᑎᑦ ᖃᐅᔨᔭᕐᑐᕐᓗᑎ ᐃᖃᓇᐃᔭᕈᒪᔪᑦ ᖃᓄᐃᓕᐅᕆᐊᖃᕐᒪᖔᑕ, ᐊᒻᒪᓗ ᐅᖃᐅᓯᓴᖃᕈᕕᑦ ᑐᓴᕈᒪᔪᒍ. ᐊᔾᔨᖑᓪᓗ ᑕᑯᓗᑦ ᑐᑭᓯᓂᐊᕐᕋᕕᑦᑦ. ᖃᐅᔨᒪᓗᑎ ᐅᓪᓗᖏᑦ ᐃᑲᕋᓪᓗ ᐊᓯᓪᓕᑐᐃᓐᓇᕆᐊᓖᑦ
